Award.AwardTitle: 2019 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES)-National Science Foundation (NSF) Special Sessions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The BMES Annual Meeting is highly interdisciplinary and is the premiere conference for the Biomedical Engineering community, offering programming at the forefront of discovery and education to leading researchers, professionals, leaders and students in the BME field. The BMES Annual Meeting is an ideal venue to hold the BMES-NSF Special Sessions to engage the broadest possible participation, and to stimulate conversations, questions & answers, and new mentoring relationships across faculty, students and professionals. These Special Sessions will allow audience participants to gain a greater awareness of NSF-sponsored research opportunities, attain a better understanding of how to prepare successful BME grant proposals, and offer participants a place to learn from each other as mentors and colleagues.
Two sessions are planning:
1) BMES-NSF Special Session on CAREER and UNSOLICITED Awards: This BMES-NSF sponsored Special Session is expected to be held at the 2019 BMES Annual Meeting on Friday, October 18, 2019. The goal of the session is to bring together NSF Bioengineering and Engineering Healthcare grantees, young investigators, junior and senior faculty, and postdoctoral trainees for idea exchange and networking related to conducting and funding cutting-edge research in BME.

2) BMES-NSF Special Session on Graduate Research Fellowships Program (GRFP): This BMES-NSF sponsored Special Session is expected to be held at the 2019 BMES Annual Meeting on Saturday, October 19, 2019. The goal of the session is to bring together program officers, grantees, reviewers and graduate students to highlight the NSF GRFP and inform undergraduate and graduate students on GFRP guidelines and strategies to develop winning GRFP grant proposals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2019, the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES)  brought the BMES-NSF Special Session on Research in Biomedical Engineering (BME) and Grant Writing to the BMES Annual Meeting for the seventh time in Philadelphia and expanded with a session for graduate students for a third time. The CAREER and UNSOLICITED Awards session convened on Friday, October 18, 2019 and the Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) session was held on Saturday, October 19, 2019.

The NSF CAREER and UNSOLICITED Awards session drew 115 attendees and just over 50 attended the GRFP session. The BMES-NSF Special Sessions focused on promoting and sustaining innovative research in BME and covered essential elements to developing successful NSF grant proposals in topics of relevance to BME. These sessions delivered examples of successfully awarded engineering research from the NSF, allowing audience participants to gain a greater awareness of NSF-sponsored research opportunities, attain a better understanding of how to prepare successful BME grant proposals, and offered participants a place to learn from each other as mentors and colleagues.

The BMES-NSF sponsored Special Sessions at the 2019 BMES Annual Meeting engaged students, faculty, aspiring faculty and practitioners in the field. Each panel was organized to have speakers that represented a diversity of institutions (public/private, strongly funded or not) at different stages of their awards, as well as diversity of gender, race and ethnicity. Many panelists supported to attend the BMES also presented their research in the many tracks and sessions offered at the Annual Meeting, giving travel award recipients the opportunity to showcase their research success. The sessions brought together biomedical and bioengineering researchers and investigators, program directors and reviewers, who may not otherwise have had the chance to collaborate, exchange ideas and network about conducting and funding cutting-edge research in BME. The sessions highlighted NSF funded research, informed participants on developing winning grant proposals and provided opportunity for networking and community building for those directing or aspiring to direct independent research.

The sessions contributed to a comprehensive approach by BMES in partnership with NSF to ensure development of a diverse technically competent biomedical engineering workforce.
